episodeTitle: Boss Luffy is the Culprit? Track Down the Missing Great Cherry Tree!
episodeTitleJapanese: 犯人はルフィ親分？消えた大桜を追え
episodeTitleRomanized: Hannin wa Rufi oyabun? Kieta oozakura o oe
description: In an alternate reality set in feudal Japan, Detective Luffy and the townspeople prepare for the cherry blossom festival. When young Ninjin falls ill and the ancient thousand-year-old sakura tree mysteriously vanishes, suspicion falls on Luffy. The truth reveals Buggy and Foxy as the thieves.

credits.artDirector: Miho Shiraishi, Michiyo Kawasaki, Kumiko Fukuzawa

events.title: Ninjin Falls Ill Before the Festival
events.description: In feudal Grand Jipangu, young Ninjin becomes sick just one day before the annual cherry blossom viewing festival. Doctor Chopper examines him and determines he's too ill to attend the celebration, disappointing both Ninjin and Luffy.
events.significance: Sets up the emotional stakes for the episode and establishes Luffy's motivation to help Ninjin see the cherry blossoms despite his illness.

quotes.text: I wish I could find a way to show Ninjin the thousand-year sakura.
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy expresses his desire to help the sick child see the cherry blossoms

events.title: The Thousand-Year Sakura Tree
events.description: The townspeople prepare for the annual hanami festival centered around the legendary thousand-year-old cherry blossom tree, a cherished symbol of the community where everyone gathers for picnics under its blooms.
events.significance: Establishes the cultural importance of the sakura tree to Grand Jipangu and explains why its theft will be such a serious crime.

events.title: Festival Day Arrives - The Tree is Missing
events.description: The day of the hanami festival arrives, but when the townspeople gather at the park, they discover with shock and dismay that the thousand-year-old cherry blossom tree has completely vanished overnight.
events.significance: Introduces the central mystery of the episode and triggers the investigation that will occupy the rest of the story.

events.title: Usopp Suspects Luffy of the Theft
events.description: Remembering Luffy's earlier words about wanting to show Ninjin the cherry blossoms, Usopp concludes that Luffy must have stolen the tree to fulfill the sick child's wish. He shares this theory with Nami and Sanji at their cafeteria, the Pinwheel.
events.significance: Creates false suspicion and dramatic irony as the audience knows Luffy wouldn't commit such a crime, setting up the eventual revelation of the true culprits.

events.title: Luffy Shows Ninjin a Cherry Blossom Branch
events.description: Usopp and Sanji find Luffy at Ninjin's house, where he's showing the sick boy a small cherry blossom branch. Usopp assumes this is evidence of Luffy's theft and begins interrogating him, but Luffy firmly denies all accusations.
events.significance: Demonstrates Luffy's genuine care for Ninjin while the branch serves as a red herring, temporarily convincing others of his guilt.

events.title: Robin Discovers the Stolen Tree
events.description: Robin spots the missing thousand-year-old cherry blossom tree on a pirate ship in the harbor. She immediately notifies the other Straw Hats, who rush to the location to investigate and confront the thieves.
events.significance: Solves the mystery and clears Luffy's name while identifying the true culprits, advancing the plot to the confrontation phase.

events.title: Buggy and Foxy's Criminal Partnership Exposed
events.description: The theft is revealed to be a joint operation between Buggy and Foxy. Buggy agreed to steal the tree for Foxy in exchange for 10,000,000 beli. However, their partnership immediately falls apart when Foxy reveals he lied about the payment.
events.significance: Establishes the villain team-up and their mercenary motivations while immediately introducing conflict between the antagonists themselves.

events.title: Buggy vs Foxy - Betrayal Leads to Combat
events.description: Enraged by Foxy's betrayal about the payment, Buggy fires a Buggy Ball at him. Foxy retaliates by using his Noro Noro no Mi powers, firing a slow-slow beam that decelerates the Buggy Ball mid-flight.
events.significance: Demonstrates both villains' signature abilities and shows them fighting each other, making them easier targets for the heroes.

events.title: Foxy Uses Noro Noro Beam
events.description: Foxy demonstrates his Noro Noro no Mi Devil Fruit ability, emitting special microscopic photon particles as beams of light that slow down anything they hit for 30 seconds. He attempts to use this power on Zoro as well during the confrontation.
events.significance: Showcases Foxy's signature Devil Fruit power in this alternate universe setting, maintaining consistency with his abilities from the main series.

events.title: Zoro Deflects the Noro Noro Beam
events.description: When Foxy fires his slow-slow beam at Zoro, the swordsman monk parries it with his sword, reflecting the beam back. The deflected beam accidentally hits Buggy instead, slowing down the clown pirate.
events.significance: Demonstrates Zoro's combat skill and quick thinking while exploiting Foxy's known weakness to reflective surfaces, turning the villain's power against his own ally.

events.title: Luffy Defeats Both Villains
events.description: Detective Luffy confronts the thieves and defeats them both. He punches Foxy with a Gomu Gomu no Pistol while wielding a sword, sending him flying. Then he uses Gomu Gomu no Gatling Gun on Buggy, scattering the clown's separated body parts across the harbor.
events.significance: Resolves the conflict through Luffy's signature fighting techniques adapted to this feudal setting, showing he retains his Devil Fruit powers even in this alternate reality.

quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy uses his signature attack while holding a sword

events.title: The Cherry Tree is Returned to the Village
events.description: After defeating Buggy and Foxy, the Straw Hats retrieve the thousand-year-old sakura tree and transport it back using Foxy's ship. They display it prominently so all the villagers can see it, including the bedridden Ninjin.
events.significance: Restores the cultural treasure to the community and ensures the festival can proceed as planned, fulfilling the episode's central goal.

events.title: Ninjin's Miraculous Recovery
events.description: When Ninjin sees the blooming thousand-year-old cherry blossom tree from his window, his spirits lift immediately and his health improves almost miraculously. Doctor Chopper acknowledges that the sight of the beautiful sakura has cured the boy's illness.
events.significance: Provides a heartwarming resolution to Ninjin's subplot and reinforces themes about the healing power of nature, beauty, and community. Demonstrates that Luffy's wish to show Ninjin the cherry blossoms was fulfilled after all.

quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy expresses concern for sick Ninjin before the festival

quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy defeats Foxy with his signature attack

themes.description: The episode emphasizes the importance of caring for those who are sick and ensuring everyone can participate in cultural celebrations. Luffy's desire to help Ninjin see the cherry blossoms drives the emotional core of the story.
themes.symbolism: The thousand-year-old cherry blossom tree represents the enduring bonds of community and the healing power of natural beauty.
culturalReferences: Hanami (cherry blossom viewing) is a traditional Japanese custom celebrating the transient beauty of sakura
The feudal Japanese setting references the Edo period
Cherry blossoms symbolize the ephemeral nature of life in Japanese culture

themes.description: The episode plays with false accusations and mistaken assumptions, as Luffy is wrongly suspected of the theft when he was actually trying to help. The cherry blossom branch serves as misleading evidence.
themes.symbolism: The investigation and revelation of the true culprits demonstrates that jumping to conclusions without evidence can harm innocent people.

characterSpotlights.development: In this alternate reality, Luffy maintains his core compassionate nature, showing deep concern for sick Ninjin and working to ensure the boy can experience the cherry blossom festival. He clears his name and defeats the actual thieves.

characterSpotlights.development: Ninjin's illness and disappointment at missing the festival creates the emotional stakes for the episode. His miraculous recovery upon seeing the cherry blossoms provides a heartwarming conclusion.

characterSpotlights.development: Foxy orchestrates the theft of the cherry tree and betrays his partner Buggy by lying about payment, showing his cunning and dishonest nature even in this alternate setting.

characterSpotlights.development: Buggy agrees to steal the tree for monetary gain but is betrayed by Foxy. His anger at being cheated leads to conflict with his partner before both are defeated.

mangaDifferences.difference: This entire episode is anime-original filler content with no manga equivalent. The Boss Luffy Historical Special arc is a completely non-canon alternate universe story created exclusively for the anime.

trivia.fact: This episode aired on April 1st, 2007 (April Fools' Day), and featured a special version of the 'Crazy Rainbow' opening with Tackey & Tsubasa (the singers) animated into the intro alongside the Straw Hats.
Episode 303 is part of the Boss Luffy Historical Special, which spans 6 episodes across multiple years (SP4, 291-292, 303, and 406-407) from 2005-2009.

sources.title: Boss Luffy Historical Special - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The Boss Luffy episodes are set in 'Grand Jipangu,' an alternate universe based on 19th century feudal Japan during the Edo period, with Straw Hat crew members taking on different historical roles.

sources.title: Boss Luffy Historical Special - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: Ninjin originally appeared in the Syrup Village Arc as a member of the Usopp Pirates. His appearance in this episode represents a crossover bringing an East Blue character into the filler storyline.
This episode has no ending theme because Toei Animation stopped airing ending themes from episode 279 to episode 1070, a gap of nearly 17 years.

sources.title: One Piece Music - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: Despite being set in an alternate universe without pirate crews, characters retain their Devil Fruit powers - Luffy has his Gomu Gomu abilities, Foxy has Noro Noro, and Buggy has Bara Bara.
The episode aired between canon Enies Lobby arc episodes, providing a comedic break during one of One Piece's most intense story arcs.
